div.h3: Board of Education Meeting Notification - April 28, 2020

div.span: REGULAR MEETING OF THE BOARD OF EDUCATION OF THE SMITHTOWN CENTRAL SCHOOL DISTRICT April 28, 2020 6:00 p.m. The meeting will be held remotely by videoconference with no in person attendance. It is anticipated that at 6:00 p.m. the Board will make a motion for the purpose of adjourning into executive session and that at approximately 7:00 p.m. the Board of Education will reconvene in public session. The public will be able to view and/or listen to the meeting by joining "Facebook Live" which will be broadcast from the Smithtown Central School District Facebook page which can be reached with the following web address: https://www.facebook.com/SmithtownSchools/live. Although there will be no public in-person participation at this meeting, the Board of Education encourages the public to submit any questions or comments via email to boe@smithtown.k12.ny.us by 4:00pm on April 28, 2020. The Board will do it's best to address these questions and comments during the meeting.

div.h3: POSTPONED: School Budget Vote and Trustee Election
div.div: POSTPONED - Due to Executive Order No 202.13 the NYS School Budget Vote and Election has been postponed. As soon as we receive more guidance from the Governor's Office we will update the community.

img.title: Graffiti Walls Showcase Literacy at Mt. Pleasant

h3.a: Graffiti Walls Showcase Literacy at Mt. Pleasant

div.p: Before schools closed, the fifth graders at Mt. Pleasant Elementary School worked with the district’s English language arts coach Patricia Gallery to deepen their understanding of theme analysis and application. After identifying the themes of common songs and articulating the themes in complete sentences, students shared ideas about how understanding themes can help us to be better humans. As a culminating activity, students used clues from the blurb and book jacket to infer theme... Click Here to View

Instilling a lifelong love of reading is the main objective of the Book Club at Nesaquake Middle School. Run by English teacher Marissa LoSardo, the club works to promote a love of reading in their school community.
Using social media, the club shares many of the popular books they are reading with their school community. Students in the clubs do book reviews and conduct interviews with teachers and students who are “readers of the week,” sharing information about their current... Click Here to View

Prior to the closing of schools, an art lesson brought food truck designs came to life. Fourth graders at Mt. Pleasant Elementary School have been designing their own food truck concepts during their art classes with Mrs. Lindbom. Many of the students used their families’ favorite recipes to inspire their concepts. Some of the mobile restaurant designs included fondue, crepes, sushi or El Salvadorian pupusa.
Click Here to View

During the past few years, High School West has transformed its library from a traditional space to a learning commons. The library features different sections based on student needs and includes areas for conversational study, quiet study and considerate study.
“We wanted to have a space where students could have quiet time to study or work on projects and collaborate together,” said High School West librarian Cathy Masrour. “These students are really learning 21st century... Click Here to View

We are starting an exciting project that will be part of the district's history for years to come. All students are welcome and encouraged to participate. The Smithtown Central School District’s mascot is the bull. This is due to the historical significance it possesses. We are looking for a new design for the bull logo/mascot. All designs will be submitted to the Logo Committee, which will determine the next steps of the contest. All participants are eligible for prizes which are... Click Here to View

div.h3: Graffiti Walls Showcase Literacy at Mt. Pleasant
div.div: Before schools closed, the fifth graders at Mt. Pleasant Elementary School worked with the district’s English language arts coach Patricia Gallery to deepen their understanding of theme analysis and application. After identifying the themes of common songs and articulating the themes in complete sentences, students shared ideas about how understanding themes can help us to be better humans. As a culminating activity, students used clues from the blurb and book jacket to infer theme statements and created mini graffiti walls to showcase the book covers and themes.

div.div:
Instilling a lifelong love of reading is the main objective of the Book Club at Nesaquake Middle School. Run by English teacher Marissa LoSardo, the club works to promote a love of reading in their school community.
Using social media, the club shares many of the popular books they are reading with their school community. Students in the clubs do book reviews and conduct interviews with teachers and students who are “readers of the week,” sharing information about their current favorite title.
To show how reading can also be fun, they promote their favorite titles and use their club time to share why they love their current reading selections with members. The club meets twice a month on Monday mornings. Check out all their happenings on Instagram at @nesaquake_book_love. On their page, the club posts reading and book loving memes and reposts novels from authors or publishing companies to share titles of interesting books.
They create “questions of the month” for classmates to fill out and discuss about reading. There’s also a bulletin board in the cafeteria that is updated monthly to reflect different themes.

div.div: Prior to the closing of schools, an art lesson brought food truck designs came to life. Fourth graders at Mt. Pleasant Elementary School have been designing their own food truck concepts during their art classes with Mrs. Lindbom. Many of the students used their families’ favorite recipes to inspire their concepts. Some of the mobile restaurant designs included fondue, crepes, sushi or El Salvadorian pupusa.

div.div:
During the past few years, High School West has transformed its library from a traditional space to a learning commons. The library features different sections based on student needs and includes areas for conversational study, quiet study and considerate study.
“We wanted to have a space where students could have quiet time to study or work on projects and collaborate together,” said High School West librarian Cathy Masrour. “These students are really learning 21st century skills here; and much of that work is being self-directed.”
For example, one area of the library features a 3D printer and gathered around the printer are some of the amazing student designs. Students have the ability to work on their areas of interest, create 3D projects and even mentor other students. More than a dozen student aides are available to assist in the library.
The learning commons allows for students to work autonomously and become collaborative and flexible in their learning. In the traditional learning space, a ninth grade English class spends the period sharing their independent book reviews. Another area of the library features a tower garden, a self-feeder-type planter that is cared for by the students. The planter self regulates on a timer for the proper amount of water and light.
The High School West library wants to make sure that students and staff are effective users of ideas and information. It supports collaborative and independent learning. For example, one student recently created his own mini-computer that can be powered off of a small power bank using tutorials found online. The library’s emphasis is on the development of skills necessary for work and life in a global, increasingly digital world.

div.div:
We are starting an exciting project that will be part of the district's history for years to come. All students are welcome and encouraged to participate. The Smithtown Central School District’s mascot is the bull. This is due to the historical significance it possesses. We are looking for a new design for the bull logo/mascot. All designs will be submitted to the Logo Committee, which will determine the next steps of the contest. All participants are eligible for prizes which are outlined in the link below. The newly designed bull logo will be used on athletic uniforms, school banners, school marketing items, etc.
This is a fun and creative project that students can be involved with individually, as a family or with classmates (via Google Meet, Zoom, FaceTime, etc.). YOU can be the creator of the NEW SMITHTOWN BULL!
So get involved and be part of the future of the Smithtown Central School District! Please click on the following link to review Logo Contest information and details: https://bit.ly/SCSDLogoContest

Fifth graders at Mt. Pleasant Elementary School learned about the importance of keeping drinking water clean thanks to a presentation from the Suffolk County Water Authority. After learning about the water cycle and how the water authority cleans and filters water on Long Island, the students witnessed a groundwater simulation. Fourth graders at Dogwood Elementary School were recently given an online assignment on Google classroom. They were asked to “share some smiles” and write a few things about what they have been doing while they are at home with their families. Along with photos, each student created their own slide, which the teachers posted together as a slideshow for the entire grade. Read Full Story >

div.h3: Towers Build STEM Skills and More
div.div: Before the schools closed last month, fifth graders in Mrs. Walsh and Mrs. Floyd’s class at Smithtown Elementary School completed a STEM challenge to build the highest structure using marshmallows and uncooked spaghetti. The towers could be built using any guidelines except the marshmallows could not be altered. The challenge helped the students not only with their STEM skills, but also builds teamwork and communication.

div.div: Before the closing of the schools, Alexandra Stevens, marine educator, Cornell University Cooperative Extension of Suffolk County, presented program on the magic of bioluminescence to the fifth graders at St. James Elementary School. After learning about some of the bioluminescent plants, animals and bacteria on land, the students learned about the deep sea’s midnight zone, where most of the bioluminescent creatures live. Ms. Stevens spoke to the students about the science behind their bioluminescence, such as camouflaging, attracting mates, communicating, or scaring and luring in predators.

div.div: Fifth graders at Mt. Pleasant Elementary School learned about the importance of keeping drinking water clean thanks to a presentation from the Suffolk County Water Authority. After learning about the water cycle and how the water authority cleans and filters water on Long Island, the students witnessed a groundwater simulation. Different pollutants – simulating oil and gas – were leaked into the simulator. Students could see how these pollutants and others such as cesspools and fertilizers, could have a lifelong effect on our water.
